unicode.value: Isabel García
Medical English 1 lesson
master class
closed exercise or problem
real project
didactic game
open problem
conceptual map
Sección
Did you know that...?

Did you know that the Egyptians were the first ones to describe the kidneys? In 2018 a papyrus of 3500 years was found and it contained a description of the kidneys and other medical understandings. 

We can't read the papyrus but we can learn about them and other organs with the article "Anatomy of the kidney and ureter" by Vishy Mahadevan.

Survey
Text and Tasks

By the end of this activity you will be able to identify and enunciate:

  • The vascular anatomy of the upper urinary tract organs.
  • Its topographical relation.
  • Vascular and topographical anatomy of the suprarenal glands.
Text and Tasks
Urinary tract?

The urinary tract is divided into:

  • Upper urinary tract:  kidneys and ureters
  • Low urinary tract:  urinary bladder and urethra

Let's see if you can identify these organs. Do the following activity.
Text and Tasks
Java Applet
University of Auckland
"Find the .txt file (in the applet file) and open it. Copy the contents of this file <ctrl A, ctrl C> into the applet code field.
Add all the files provided for the applet except the .txt file one at a time using the add files and upload buttons. The files, once loaded will be displayed beneath the Applet code field.

If the applet you're adding was generated by one of the programs in this drop down, please select it, then add the data/applet file generated by your program.

eg. For Geogebra applets, select geogebra, then add the .ggb file that you created in Geogebra.

Match the parts of the urinary tract with its name.

kidney

ureter

bladder

urethra

upper urinary tract

low urinary tract
In this session we are focusing on the upper urinary tract and the suprarenal glands.
Text and Tasks
Let's learn!

Read the article "Anatomy of the kidney and ureter" and colocate the subtitles in the correct place. Write the subtitle of the box in the space with the number that corresponds to the blanc in the text. Pay attention to the capital letters and the correct spelling.
Text and Tasks
What's its subtitle?
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

1. The kidney

2.  Topographical relations of the kidney

3.  The blood supply of the kidney

4.  Pelvicalyceal system of the kidney

5.  The ureter

6.  Topographical relations of the ureter

7.  The blood supply of the ureter

8. The suprarenal glands

9.  Blood supply of the suprarenal gland

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Let's put it into practice...
Anatomy of the kidney
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Anterior relations on the left side.htm

string.value: Anterior relations on the left side.htm

unicode.value: Topographical relations of the kidney
Do the following matching exercises about the topographical relations of the kidney.
Text and Tasks
The ureter
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Read the sentences and write A if the sentence is about the anatomy of the ureter or T if it is about the topographic relation of the ureter.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

T The abdominal ureter descends in a straight line on the anterior aspect of psoas major.

A The length of the ureter in the adult is 25-30 cm.

A The wall of the ureter is made up of an inner mucosal layer.

T The genitofemoral nerve having emerged from the psoas major runs beneath the psoas fascia, behind the ureter.

A It exhibits peristaltic movement thanks to interlacing smooth muscle fibres.

A Outside the muscle coat is an adventitial layer containing a delicate network of blood vessels.

T The anterior topographical relations of the ureter, however, differ between the right and left sides, and within the pelvic cavity they differ between the sexes.

A The ureter may be said to have two segments: an abdominal segment and a pelvic segment.

T Lying across the front of the upper end of the left ureter is the body of the pancreas.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

T The abdominal ureter descends in a straight line on the anterior aspect of psoas major.

A The length of the ureter in the adult is 25-30 cm.

A The wall of the ureter is made up of an inner mucosal layer.

T The genitofemoral nerve having emerged from the psoas major runs beneath the psoas fascia, behind the ureter.

A It exhibits peristaltic movement thanks to interlacing smooth muscle fibres.

A Outside the muscle coat is an adventitial layer containing a delicate network of blood vessels.

T The anterior topographical relations of the ureter, however, differ between the right and left sides, and within the pelvic cavity they differ between the sexes.

A The ureter may be said to have two segments: an abdominal segment and a pelvic segment.

T Lying across the front of the upper end of the left ureter is the body of the pancreas.
The abdominal ureter descends in a straight line on the anterior aspect of psoas major.
The length of the ureter in the adult is 25-30 cm.
The wall of the ureter is made up of an inner mucosal layer.
The genitofemoral nerve having emerged from the psoas major runs beneath the psoas fascia, behind the ureter.
It exhibits peristaltic movement thanks to interlacing smooth muscle fibres.
Outside the muscle coat is an adventitial layer containing a delicate network of blood vessels.
The anterior topographical relations of the ureter, however, differ between the right and left sides, and within the pelvic cavity they differ between the sexes.
The ureter may be said to have two segments: an abdominal segment and a pelvic segment.
Lying across the front of the upper end of the left ureter is the body of the pancreas.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.
Suprarenal glands
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Complete the summary of the last part of the article with the letters of the phrases from the box.
University of Auckland
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Right suprarenal gland

Left suprarenal gland

Anatomy

D

Surrounded by perinephric fat which, in turn, is enveloped in renal fascia.

Shape

E

C

Topography

Posteriorly it lies on the right crus of the diaphragm. Anteriorly it is overlapped by the inferior vena cava medially and by the bare area of the liver laterally.

A

Blood supply

The abdominal aorta, the ipsilateral renal artery and ipsilateral inferior phrenic artery.

Venous drainage

B

Drains into the left renal vein.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Shape

Topography

Posteriorly it lies on the right crus of the diaphragm. Anteriorly it is overlapped by the inferior vena cava medially and by the bare area of the liver laterally.

In resume...

Interesting right? Were there things you already knew? Let's check all the things you learned today!

Match the resume to the corresponding organ.

Activity validation
Validate your activity

Duración:
10:00

To finish this activity you will answer a validation quiz. It is important to consider these things:

       1. To get this activity validated, you must score at least 80% in this quiz.

       2. In order not to lose points, it is important to check not only your answer but your spelling too.

Click here:                validation quiz
Text and Tasks

• Mahadevan, V. (2019) Anatomy of the kidney and ureter. Elsevier
  • National Institute of Diabetes and Digestive and Kidney Diseases. (2020) Urinary tract [image] Retrieved from: https://www.niddk.nih.gov/health-information/urologic-diseases/urinary-tract-how-it-works 
  • Petsko, E. (2019) 11 Facts about the kidneys. Mental Floss. Retrieved: https://www.mentalfloss.com/article/574564/kidney-facts 
  • Raible, E. (2020) Kidney Transplant Improves Cardiovascular Reserve, But Not For Reasons You Might Think. [image] Retrieves from:https://www.docwirenews.com/docwire-pick/cardiology-picks/kidney-transplant-cardiovascular-improvements-left-ventricular-mass/
